author: sacha6557
content:
> <@!550420431744794624> or anyone. Have we already talked about eip-2334 and the potential desire for withdrawal keys and signing keys to remain entirely separate? 2334 requires that signing keys be a child of the withdrawal key...
> 
> 
<@!399309815517544451> perhaps this can be seen as a feature, and not a bug?

While your funds can't be moved without the withdrawal key, as it stands the signing key is needed to initiate a withdrawal.

If you choose to use a staking provider, you will have to hand over control of your signing key.

This means your ability to exit, if they go offline, or you're unhappy with the service you're receiving, depends on them. 

In other words, when you use a staking provider, you surrender your control over your ability to exit, *unless* you're able to re-derive your signing key from your withdrawal key and initiate an exit yourself.

P.S. As far as I understand, although it is possible to do the key exchange in a way that obligates your staking provider to provide you with a signed exit before you submit your deposit, there is a risk that this message is invalidated by a fork. So you have the added responsibility of keeping track of the validity of that message, and possibly, multiple messages (which is not great from a UX PoV)

content: Not to pick apart your idea too much, but just because you give the staking provider a copy of your signing key doesn't mean you have no ability to exit

author: prestonvanloon
content: And it doesn't have to be derived by the withdrawal key

> Not to pick apart your idea too much, but just because you give the staking provider a copy of your signing key doesn't mean you have no ability to exit

Right, but it does protect against the case in which they own the signing key.

> I think it's a risk to bring your cold wallet out of "cold storage" to restore your hot key

It's obviously a risk. but this would be a worst case scenario sort of thing.

author: djrtwo
content:
a staking provider can also provide you with the signed exit before you submit your deposit. and you can refuse submitting that deposit until they do so
(note this is not resistant to change of fork in eth2, but dual key exits are generally agreed upon as going in soon)
